Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Evaluating the Impact of an Unusual Meteorite at the Onset of Younger Dryas Using a Greenland Ice Core
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Younger Dryas is a major cooling period from 12,900 to 11,600 years before present subsequent to the last glaciation. The cause of this abrupt cooling is poorly understood. A highly controversial hypothesis suggests that a number of meteorite or comet impacts triggered sudden release of meltwater from proglacial Lake Agassiz (Great Lakes), disrupting oceanic circulation, and eventually leading to long term cooling. Recently, remarkably high Platinum and low Iridium concentrations have been discovered in the Greenland ice core at the onset of Younger Dryas, indicating an unusually Platinum enriched iron meteorite impact. However, another study suggested that these abnormal concentrations could be from weathering of ancient terrestrial material. Therefore, this project will analyze another ice core from Greenland to substantiate the recent discovery and determine the nature of meteorite. The project will be performed in collaboration with Dr. Sungmin Hong at Inha University in Korea, and his collaborators at Korea Polar Research Institute, who are experts in Platinum and Iridium analyses in ice cores. This research will provide insight into the cause of an abrupt cooling climate during Younger Dryas, and advance understanding of mechanisms of climate change.

The research will determine Platinum and Iridium concentrations at the onset of Younger Dryas in the North Greenland Ice Core Project (NGRIP) ice core. These analyses are technically challenging as ice samples require decontamination of the NGRIP ice core, which could have been contaminated during drilling, and high sensitivity measurements of platinum metals, whose concentrations in the ice are expected to be extremely low (in 10-15g/g or femtogram/g). This project aims to decontaminate the NGRIP ice core in ultraclean working conditions and measure Platinum and Iridium using sector-field inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-SFMS). This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the National Research Foundation of Korea.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this research is to investigate Platinum and Iridium contents of the Greenland Ice Core Project (GRIP) ice core to observe extraterrestrial signal during the Younger Dryas abrupt cooling interlude (12,900 to 11,600 years BP). In order to do so, the research at Inha University, Korea, and Korea Polar Research Institute (KOPRI) mainly focused on decontamination (surface removal) of the GRIP ice core and establishment of controlled settings for Platinum and Iridium measurements in ice. In ice core samples, Platinum and Iridium concentrations are extremely low (10-15g/g or fg/g), making them highly vulnerable to contamination. Furthermore, the surface of the ice core section is heavily contaminated due to ice drilling and handling processes. Therefore, the decontamination of the ice is highly critical for ultra-low concentrations. For the purpose of reducing contamination of the ice core samples, several experiments were performed to determine decontamination procedural blanks of man-made ice prior to decontaminating the GRIP ice core. The decontamination was achieved through mechanical chiseling of each layer of ice from the outer contaminated part to inner part of the ice, three outer layers and a clean inner core. Then, each veneer layer was processed for the Platinum and Iridium contributions from the chiseling using Inductively Coupled Plasma Sector-Field Mass Spectrometry (ICP-SFMS). With regard to measuring exceptionally low Platinum and Iridium concentrations, a pre-concentration method, sub-boiling evaporation, was used to enhance the sensitivity of the measurements in ICP-SFMS. This method was tested for Platinum and Iridium contents introduced during the procedure (Platinum and Iridium introduced <<10% of the expected sample concentration, <1fg/g) for controlled measurements in ice.

 

The Younger Dryas cooling event is one of the major rapid changes in climate. By obtaining independent evidence of Platinum and Iridium at the onset of the Younger Dryas, the project can give information of the source of the cooling climate and earth’s response to changes in the environment. Thus, the project will stimulate research in the field of climatology, astronomy, geochemistry, and geology relating to the Younger Dryas. 

 

The EAPSI program provided me opportunities to experience the foreign research culture, to interact and cooperate with international researchers, and to perform experiments under foreign laboratory settings. Furthermore, during the visit I obtained ice decontamination skills and learned to better manage clean laboratory settings for glaciochemistry. The research in Korea will be part of my dissertation and will be used to elaborate my future research of analyzing Platinum and Iridium concentrations in another Greenland ice core.
